correspAction.name: Supreme Court of Victoria, Probate Jurisdiction

div.p: FromAlexander Buettner, Hermann Buettner and William Potter to Supreme Court of Victoria, Probate Jurisdiction
No. 62/802, unit 802, VPRS 28 Probate and Administration Files, VA 2624, Public Record Office, Victoria.

note.p:
Thetypescriptstatement of Assets and Liabilitiesispart of the bundle of papers related to the grant of probate of M's will dated 17 June 1884 (in this edition as 84-06-17). Thepapers includeaffidavits concerning James Rudall's renouncing the role of executor and the remaining executors (Alexander Buettner, Hermann Buettner and William Potter; Willliam Haig had predeceased M) swearing to the accuracy of the accounts, dated 12 November 1896; John George Luehmann and Charles French each swearing to the authenticity of the will and that the alterations in it were made before they signed as witnesses; avaluation of M'sproperty and effects(seeW.Lamb Smith to the executors,22 October 1896(in this edition as M96-10-22); a statement of the executors' account in 1900 (see
A. Buettner et al. to Supreme Court, 28 June 1900(inthis edition as M1900-06-28));and the formal grant ofprobate,dated 16 November 1896.

There is a ✓
markagainst each of the subtotals and summary entries.

There is a copy of this document at E97/3566, unit 972, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria, this having been provided to the Premier at his request by the Supreme Court's Master in Equity on 20 February 1897.

cell.p: Freehold land situate at SouthYarra having a frontage of 95 feet 9½ inches to Arnold street by a depth of 106 feet 11 inches having erected thereon a brick villa (known as Number 28 Arnold Street occupied by the deceased at the time of his death) containing 9 rooms kitchen bath-room and a weatherboard stable, thewhole in very bad repair.

p.seg: The annual municipal valuation of the said land together with the improvements thereon is £70 and the value thereof is . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

p.seg: The deceased had also at the time of his death the
George and various foreign orders which are set out in the said
which belong to the various governments which conf
There is a marginal annotation beside

note.p:
Though evidently well aware of the
obligation
to return M's
various decorations,
the executors failed to do so. What
are
reputed to be M's KCMG regalia are listed in the catalogue of the State Library of NSW, Sydney, as part of the Sir William Dixson medal collection
(star DN/M 1284, badge DN/M 1285). However ,
an expected provenance note could not be found when requested
in 2016.The Library also holds M's badge of the French Légion
d'Honneur; see Home (2017). The badges of many of M's other knighthoods came into the possession of various of his nieces and nephews,
whose descendants
have
presented them to the
Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne
where they are no w.
The Grand Cross of the Order of Christ, Kingdom of Portugal, was given toWilliam Potter's daughter, andwith the deed of gift (W. Potter et al.to Beatrice Potter,26 February 1900) these regalia arein the PowerhouseMuseum,Sydney (No. 15547).The Baronial regalia of 'crown and coronet' and badges of two orders, presumably those of St. Jago and of Isabella the Catholic which the Will specified were 'to be kept as an unsaleable and sacred heirloom in the families of my two sisters',together withother 'trifles' such as '1 scarf, 1 crochet necktie, 1 stuffed parrot' were sent to Clara Wehl by Potter late in 1897 (Clara Wehl to Louisa Mattheissen, 23 December 1897, RBMSS M100 b,Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne).
The obituary of
M's nephew, Ferdinand Edward Wehl, states that 'among the belongings of the deceased
are ...
the regalia and baronial coronet of the
late Baron von Mueller...' ( South
eastern times
(Millicent, SA) ,
28 February
1908 , p. 2) ;
the Baronial coronettes
remain in the family.

p.seg: The spaces for the amounts have been left unfilled and the form has not been signed or dated. However, the cover of the bundle carries the statement: 'I
that there is no duty payable hereon

', signed by '[F] J H Poole Officer under Sec. 96 of the Act 1060 26/11/96'. Section 96 of the Administration and Probate Act 1890 enabled a clerk in the office of the Master of the Court to be appointed to undertake the duties specified to be carried out by the Master. The seventh Schedule, part 1, specified the amounts of duty to be paid; there was no duty on amounts under £1000. This amount was not changed in the Administration and Probate Act 1892 where the scale of duty was adjusted.

cell.style: border: none; padding-top: 0in; padding-left: 0.075in; padding-bottom: 0in; padding-right: 0.075in;
